You're encountering an error because **PowerShell** does not use `&&` to separate commands like
Linux or Command Prompt. Instead, PowerShell executes commands **line by line** or uses `;` as a
separator.  ---  ### **Fix for PowerShell** Run each command **one at a time**, or use `;` to
separate them:  ```powershell mkdir templates mkdir static mkdir static/css mkdir static/js mkdir
static/images  New-Item -Path index.html -ItemType File New-Item -Path app.py -ItemType File New-
Item -Path static/css/style.css -ItemType File New-Item -Path static/js/script.js -ItemType File
New-Item -Path templates/base.html -ItemType File New-Item -Path templates/home.html -ItemType File
```  ---  ### **Alternative: Run All Commands in One Line** If you want to run all commands at once
in PowerShell, **use `;` instead of `&&`:**  ```powershell mkdir templates; mkdir static; mkdir
static/css; mkdir static/js; mkdir static/images; New-Item -Path index.html -ItemType File; New-Item
-Path app.py -ItemType File; New-Item -Path static/css/style.css -ItemType File; New-Item -Path
static/js/script.js -ItemType File; New-Item -Path templates/base.html -ItemType File; New-Item
-Path templates/home.html -ItemType File; ```  ---  ### **Why This Happened** - `&&` **is not a
valid separator** in PowerShell. It only works in **Command Prompt (CMD) or Linux (Bash)**. -
PowerShell **requires commands to be run separately** or use `;` as the separator.  ---  Ô£à **Try the
fixed commands and let me know if it works!** ­ƒÜÇ

settings that prevent running scripts by default.  ### **Fix: Allow Running Scripts in PowerShell**
You need to change the execution policy to allow running scripts. Follow these steps:  1´©ÅÔâú **Open
PowerShell as Administrator**    - Click **Start**, type **PowerShell**.    - Right-click **Windows
PowerShell** and select **Run as Administrator**.  2´©ÅÔâú **Check the Current Execution Policy**    Run
this command:    ```powershell    Get-ExecutionPolicy    ```    If it returns `Restricted`, that
means scripts are not allowed.  3´©ÅÔâú **Allow Script Execution**    Run this command to allow scripts:
```powershell    Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted -Scope CurrentUser    ```    - If prompted, type
`A` (for Yes to All) and press **Enter**.  4´©ÅÔâú **Try Activating the Virtual Environment Again**
Run:    ```powershell    .venv\Scripts\activate    ```    If successful, you should see `(venv)` in
your terminal.  5´©ÅÔâú **(Optional) Restore Default Security Settings**    If you want to restore the
default security settings after your work, you can run:    ```powershell    Set-ExecutionPolicy
Restricted -Scope CurrentUser    ```  ---  ### **Try these steps and let me know if it works!** ­ƒÜÇ

### **­ƒÜÇ What is a SaaS Business?** A **Software as a Service (SaaS)** business means you build a
**cloud-based** application that customers **pay for as a subscription**. Instead of selling a one-
time product, you offer an ongoing **AI-powered marketing automation platform** that businesses
subscribe to.  ---  ### **­ƒÆ░ Why is SaaS a Good Business Model?** SaaS businesses have **several
advantages**, especially for AI-powered applications like yours.  #### **Ô£à 1. Recurring Revenue
(More Stable Income)** - Instead of selling a product once, you **charge customers monthly or
yearly**. - This means **consistent revenue** instead of unpredictable one-time payments. - Example:
**ChatGPT Pro, Netflix, Adobe Creative Cloud** all use this model.  #### **Ô£à 2. Scalable Business
Model** - A SaaS platform is **hosted online** ÔÇô once it's built, thousands of users can access it
**without extra costs**. - No need to create **separate software** for each customer ÔÇô **everyone
uses the same system**. - As you grow, you **add more features and increase prices** instead of
selling a new product each time.  #### **Ô£à 3. Low Maintenance & Automatic Updates** - Unlike selling
**physical products**, you **own the software** and can **update it anytime**. - Customers always
have the **latest version** without needing to install anything.  #### **Ô£à 4. More Customers, Lower
Effort** - Businesses **prefer SaaS** because they donÔÇÖt have to install or maintain software. -
Since it runs **in the cloud**, they can **log in from anywhere**. - You can offer **different
pricing tiers** (Basic, Pro, Enterprise) to attract **small and large businesses**.  #### **Ô£à 5.
Higher Business Valuation (Easier to Get Investors)** - SaaS businesses are highly **valuable to
investors** because of **predictable income**. - If you later **sell the company**, a SaaS business
gets **higher valuations** than one-time sales businesses.  ---  ### **­ƒöÑ How Your AI Marketing
System Can Be a SaaS** Right now, **Creations** is being built as a **tool for AI automation**.
With **SaaS**, you **turn it into a subscription platform** that businesses **pay to use**.  ####
**Example of a SaaS Model for Your AI Marketing Automation** | Plan | Features | Price |

| | **Pro** | Multi-platform automation, AI ad optimization | **┬ú99/month** | | **Enterprise** | AI-
driven lead management, API integrations | **┬ú299+/month** |  You can **offer free trials** and
**monthly plans**, making it easier to attract businesses.  ---  ### **­ƒÆí Next Steps: Turning
Creations into a SaaS Business** Now that you know why **SaaS is powerful**, do you want to: 1´©ÅÔâú

Rename it to `cnc_operator.jpg` for easy reference.  ---  ### **2. Update the `home.html` Template**
Modify your `home.html` file to include the image and the animated text.  #### **Updated
`home.html`** ```html {% extends "base.html" %}  {% block content %} <div class="hero-section">
<div class="overlay">         <h1 class="animated-text">Precision CNC Machining</h1>         <p
class="animated-text">Delivering high-quality components with Mori Seiki technology.</p>     </div>
</div> {% endblock %} ```  ---  ### **3. Update Your CSS (`static/css/style.css`)** Now, add styles
to set the background image and add the hover animations.  #### **Updated `style.css`** ```css /*
Hero Section */ .hero-section {     position: relative;     width: 100%;     height: 80vh;
background: url('../images/cnc_operator.jpg') no-repeat center center/cover;     display: flex;
align-items: center;     justify-content: center; }  /* Overlay for Text */ .overlay {     position:
absolute;     background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); /* Dark transparent overlay */     padding: 20px;
border-radius: 10px;     text-align: center;     color: white;     opacity: 0; /* Initially hidden
*/     transition: opacity 0.5s ease-in-out; }  /* Animated Text */ .animated-text {     font-size:
2rem;     font-weight: bold;     transition: transform 0.3s ease-in-out, opacity 0.3s ease-in-out;
opacity: 0;     transform: translateY(20px); }  /* Hover Effect */ .hero-section:hover .overlay {
opacity: 1; /* Show text on hover */ }  .hero-section:hover .animated-text {     opacity: 1;
transform: translateY(0); } ```  ---  ### **4. Restart Your Flask App** After making these changes,
restart your Flask app and check your homepage.  ```sh python app.py ```  ---  ### **Effect** - The
homepage will **display the CNC operator image** as the background. - When the user **hovers over
the image**, a **dark overlay** with text will appear. - The text will **fade in and slide up
smoothly** for a polished effect.  Would you like any additional adjustments? ­ƒÜÇ

serves static files from the `static/` folder. If itÔÇÖs not working, try **removing this route** and

original file was `.webp` and you're referencing `.jpg` in CSS, check if the file was actually

correctly referencing the image, or the file path could be incorrect.  ---  ### **Steps to Fix the
Contact Page Background Image**  #### Ô£à **Step 1: Check the Image Path in `style.css`** You have:
```css .contact-hero {     position: relative;     width: 100%;     height: 80vh;     background:
url('../images/loading_image.webp') no-repeat center center/cover;     display: flex;     align-
items: center;     justify-content: center; } ``` ­ƒö╣ **Make sure the file exists in:**   ­ƒôé
`static/images/loading_image.webp`  #### **Test Fix:** Try modifying the **background URL path** in
`style.css`: ```css .contact-hero {     background: url('/static/images/loading_image.webp') no-
repeat center center/cover; } ``` Sometimes **relative paths** (`../`) don't work as expected in
Flask.  ---  #### Ô£à **Step 2: Check Image File Name & Extension** - **Ensure** `loading_image.webp`
**exists** inside `static/images/` - If unsure, rename it to **lowercase** (`loading_image.webp`) -
If `.webp` is not displaying, try converting it to `.jpg` or `.png`  ---  #### Ô£à **Step 3: Force CSS
to Reload** Your browser might be **caching the old CSS**.   Try **hard refreshing** the browser: -
**Windows:** `CTRL + SHIFT + R` - **Mac:** `CMD + SHIFT + R`  Alternatively, **append a query
string** in `style.css` link in `base.html`: ```html <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{
url_for('static', filename='css/style.css') }}?v=2"> ``` The `?v=2` forces browsers to reload the
latest styles.  ---  #### Ô£à **Step 4: Restart Flask & Check Console** 1. **Restart Flask**:    ```sh
CTRL+C    python app.py    ``` 2. **Open Console (`F12`) ÔåÆ Console/Network Tab**      - Look for

### What the error is telling you  ``` did not find executable at 'C:\Python313\python.exe' ```
When you run **`python app.py`**, the wrapper that lives inside the virtual-env looks for the
*system* Python executable it was created with ( `C:\Python313\python.exe` ).   That file is no
longer there, so every command that relies on the v-envÔÇÖs *python.exe* fails.  **Why it happens**  *
You created the v-env when a Python 3.13 preview was installed at     `C:\Python313\` (or whatever
path the installer suggested). * Since then that interpreter was moved, renamed or un-installed. * A
Windows v-env hard-codes the absolute path of the ÔÇ£realÔÇØ interpreter   into each launcher in
`.\venv\Scripts\ ÔÇª`.     If that path disappears, the v-env is broken.  ---  ## Fix in three minutes
> **TL; DR** - Delete the old v-env, create a new one with the Python you have *now*.  ```powershell
# 1 ÔÇô from the project root deactivate               # only if the old v-env is still ÔÇÿactiveÔÇÖ
Remove-Item -Recurse -Force .\venv     # or .\.venv  ÔåÉ delete the folder  # 2 ÔÇô make a fresh env
with the current interpreter py -3.11 -m venv venv    # or  py -3.12 ÔÇª  depending on what ÔÇÿpy -0ÔÇÖ
lists  # 3 ÔÇô activate it .\venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1            # PowerShell #          Ôåæ NOTE the
.ps1 extension on Windows  # 4 ÔÇô reinstall your packages pip install -r requirements.txt  # 5 ÔÇô run
the site python app.py ```  You should see:  ```  * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000 (Press CTRL+C
to quit) ```  and the pages ( Home, Contact, Services, Mori Machines ) will load without the ÔÇ£canÔÇÖt
find pythonÔÇØ error.  ---  ### If you **canÔÇÖt** delete the old v-env  You can keep the folder and
just **repair** the launchers:  ```powershell # still in the project root py -3.11 -m venv --upgrade
venv ```  `--upgrade` rewrites all the `Scripts\*.exe` launchers so they know the new Python path.
ItÔÇÖs quicker than nuking the whole directory, but deleting and re-creating is the sure-thing method.
---  ### Quick safety checks after the fix  1. **`where python`** (PowerShell) ÔåÆ should point to
`C:\MatfordManufacturingWebsite\venv\Scripts\python.exe`. 2. **`python --version`** ÔåÆ must match the
interpreter you just used with `py -3.x`. 3. **`flask --version`** (optional) ÔåÆ proves the
dependencies were re-installed.  Once those three line up, the ÔÇ£missing pythonÔÇØ problem is gone for
good - until you uninstall that system interpreter again.

PowerShell is blocking `Activate.ps1` because the default **Execution Policy** disallows running
scripts.   ThereÔÇÖs nothing wrong with the virtual-env you createdÔÇöWindows is just being cautious.
---  ## 2 safe ways to solve it  | Method | One-time / every time? | Exactly what to run |
|--------|------------------------|---------------------| | **A. Use the batch file
(`activate.bat`)** | Every time you open a new terminal |```powershell
.\venv\Scripts\activate.bat```| | **B. Relax the policy for this session only** | Each new
PowerShell window |```powershell Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope
Process```<br>*(press **A** to confirm)*<br>```.\venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1```|  > **Tip:** Method A
is quickestÔÇöno admin prompts, no policy changes.  ---  ### Quick start now (Method A)  ```powershell
cd C:\MatfordManufacturingWebsite py -m venv venv          # already created, so it just re-uses it
.\venv\Scripts\activate.bat pip install -r requirements.txt python app.py ```  YouÔÇÖll see **(venv)**
in the prompt, and Flask should start on **http://127.0.0.1:5000**.  ---  ### If you prefer the
PowerShell activation script (Method B)  1. **Run once per PowerShell session** (no admin rights
needed):     ```powershell    Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process
.\venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1    ```  2. The setting reverts as soon as you close that window.  ---
### Permanent change? (Usually unnecessary)  If you *really* want `Activate.ps1` to work every time
without the extra line:  ```powershell # Run PowerShell **as Administrator**: Set-ExecutionPolicy
-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser ```  That allows any local script (like the one in
your venv) to run, while still blocking unsigned scripts from the Internet.  ---  #### What you
should do now  1. Pick **A** (activate.bat) or **B** (temp bypass).   2. Activate the env ÔåÆ `pip
install -r requirements.txt` (only once).   3. `python app.py` ÔåÆ open the site in your browser.  Let
me know if you hit anything else!

**and** look huge | Physically resize (scale down) **once** and save a lighter copy, **then** use

both:  ---  ## 2ÔÇéFast, free ways to **physically resize** the images (one-time)  | Tool | Steps (Win
10/11, no cost) | Batch? | Keeps transparency |
|------|---------------------------|-------|-------------------| | **Windows Photos app** (built-in)
| ÔÇó Right-click ÔåÆ **Open with ÔåÆ Photos**  <br>ÔÇó **ÔÇª ÔåÆ Resize ÔåÆ Define custom**  <br>ÔÇó Put width Ôëê

| | **PowerToys Ôû║ Image Resizer** | ÔÇó Install PowerToys from MS Store  <br>ÔÇó Select files in

Ô£ö | | **Squoosh.app** (web, nothing to install) | ÔÇó Go to <https://squoosh.app>  <br>ÔÇó Drag image ÔåÆ
left sidebar **Resize**: set width 600 px  <br>ÔÇó Choose **PNGÔåÆOXIPNG** or **WebP** (quality 80)
<br>ÔÇó Download | Ô£û | Ô£ö | | **ImageMagick CLI** (if you like terminals) | ```magick input.png -resize
600x output.png``` | Ô£ö | Ô£ö |  > **Rule of thumb:** 500-600 px wide PNG/WebP Ôëê 100ÔÇô200 kB ÔÇô perfect
for a quarter-width component photo.  Place the downsized files in **`static/images/`** (keep the
same filenames or update the paths).  ---  ## 3ÔÇéShow them at **┬╝-width** and animate text on
*scroll-into-view*   *(no hover needed)*  ### 3 AÔÇéHTML layout (one ÔÇ£partÔÇØ block ÔÇô duplicate for the
other two)  ```html <!-- templates/home.html  (excerpt) --> <div class="part-section">   <img
src="{{ url_for('static', filename='images/part_spindle.png') }}"        alt="Turned spindle"
class="part-img">    <div class="part-text reveal">     <h2>Rapid Response and Delivery</h2>
<p>We machine urgent parts around-the-clock and deliver nationwide the next day.</p>   </div> </div>
```  Add the other two sections in the same way (different image + paragraph).  ### 3 BÔÇéCSS
additions **(append to your `style.css`)**  ```css /* ---- Part sections
-------------------------------------------------- */ .part-section{     display:flex;     align-
items:center;     gap:3rem;     padding:60px 5%; } .part-img{     width:25vw;               /*
roughly a quarter of the viewport */     max-width:320px;          /* don't let it explode on 4K
screens */     height:auto;     flex-shrink:0; } .part-text{     max-width:35rem; }  /* ---- Scroll-
in animation ------------------------------------------- */ .reveal{     opacity:0;
transform:translateX(60px);     transition:opacity .6s ease-out, transform .6s ease-out;
background:rgba(0,0,0,.75);      /* darker overlay box */     padding:20px;     border-radius:10px;
} .reveal.in-view{     opacity:1;     transform:translateX(0); } ```  ### 3 CÔÇéTiny JS (one-off) ÔÇô
drop in **`static/js/script.js`**  ```javascript // Scroll reveal using Intersection Observer
document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {   const observer = new
IntersectionObserver((entries) => {     entries.forEach((e) => {       if (e.isIntersecting) {
e.target.classList.add('in-view');         observer.unobserve(e.target);          // animate once
}     });   }, { threshold: 0.25 });    document.querySelectorAll('.reveal').forEach(el =>
observer.observe(el)); }); ```  Make sure your **`base.html`** already includes the script tag:

bottom of `<body>` in your project ÔÇô leave it there).*  ---  ## 4ÔÇéWorkflow summary  1. **Resize**
your three PNGs with Photos / PowerToys Image Resizer / Squoosh ÔåÆ width Ôëê 600 px (keep

as you scroll.    Quick, free, and keeps file sizeÔÇöand siteÔÇösnappy. ­ƒÜÇ

### The short answer   Yes ÔÇö you can always ÔÇ£go backÔÇØ in VS Code.   The easiest, safest way is to
put your project under **Git** (built-in to VS Code). Then every time you reach a point you like you
click **Commit**. If you later change something and donÔÇÖt like it you click **Discard** (or
**Checkout** a previous commit) and the file instantly reverts.  ---  ## 3 levels of ÔÇ£undoÔÇØ  | Level
| How to use it | Good for | |-------|---------------|----------| | **1 ┬À Undo** | `Ctrl + Z` (even
after *Save*) | Quick typo fixes while the file is still open. | | **2 ┬À VS Code Timeline** | Right-
click file ÔûÂ **Open Timeline** (VS Code keeps an auto-history per file) | YesterdayÔÇÖs one-off tweak
you want to get back. | | **3 ┬À Git**  *(recommended)* | One-click commits; revert a whole file, a
line, or the entire project any time. | Real checkpoints; easy to share or move to another PC. |
Below is the one-time Git setup and the two-click workflow VS Code gives you. *(No GitHub account is
required unless you want cloud backup.)*  ---  ## One-time setup ┬¡ÔÇô initialise Git  1. **Open the
folder**      `C:\MatfordManufacturingWebsite` in VS Code.   2. **Open the built-in terminal**
*Menu ÔûÂ Terminal ÔûÂ New Terminal* (bottom panel opens in the correct folder).   3. Type:
```powershell    git init              # creates an empty repo    git add .             # stage
every current file    git commit -m "Baseline before styling resize"    ```  4. VS Code now shows a
Source-Control icon ¾░èó with **0 changes** ÔÇö that is your clean restore point.  *(If you get ÔÇ£git :
The term 'git' is not recognizedÔÇØ, install Git for Windows from <https://git-scm.com/downloads> and
reopen VS Code.)*  ---  ## Day-to-day workflow (2 clicks)  1. **Edit files** as normal.      VS
CodeÔÇÖs Source-Control icon now shows a badge (e.g. ÔÇ£3ÔÇØ) for files you touched. 2. **Want to keep the
change?**      *Source Control panel ÔûÂ Ô£ô Commit* ÔåÆ enter a short message (ÔÇ£Shrink heroes to 50 vhÔÇØ).
ThatÔÇÖs your new checkpoint. 3. **DonÔÇÖt like the change?**      *Source Control panel ÔûÂ right-click
the file ÔûÂ Discard Changes*      ÔÇô or ÔÇô      `git restore path/to/file.css` in the terminal.
The file snaps back to the last commit instantly.  If you break several files and just want
yesterdayÔÇÖs version:  ```powershell git log                   # copy the commit hash you want git
checkout <hash> -- .  # restores every file to that commit ```  *(You can always return to the
latest work with `git checkout main`.)*  ---  ## Extra safety ÔÇô push to a private GitHub repo
(optional)  ```powershell git remote add origin https://github.com/<you>/matford.git git branch -M
main git push -u origin main   # first push ```  Now any PC with Git can `git clone` and youÔÇÖre back
in business in one minute.  ---  ### Why Git is the easiest long-term  * One tool handles **full
history, branching, backups**. * Integrated in VS Code ÔÇö no extra apps, just click Ô£ô or Discard. *
You never worry ÔÇ£did I save a copy?ÔÇØ; every commit is a snapshot you can restore or compare.  Go
ahead and run `git init` once, make that baseline commit, and youÔÇÖll be free to experiment knowing
one click gets you back. If you need help with any Git command tomorrow, just ask!

### Easiest way (built-in Windows Explorer)  1. **Put the folder in Details view**      *Open the
folder ÔåÆ click ÔÇ£ViewÔÇØ ÔûÂ ÔÇ£DetailsÔÇØ (makes it simple to see the order).*  2. **Sort the files into the
order you want the numbers to follow**      *Click a column header (Name, Date modified, etc.).*
> Windows uses the current sort when it adds ÔÇ£ (1) ÔÇØ, ÔÇ£ (2) ÔÇØÔÇª so put the file that should become
**01** at the top of the list.  3. **Select all the images**      *Click the first file, hold
**Shift**, click the last ÔÇô or press **Ctrl +A**.*  4. **Press **F2** (or right-click ÔûÂ Rename)**
The top-most file name turns editable.  5. **Type your new base name** (e.g. **parts**) and press
**Enter**.      Windows instantly renames the whole batch:    ```    parts (1).png    parts (2).png
parts (3).png    ÔÇª    ```  ThatÔÇÖs itÔÇöno extra software, no scripts.  ---  ### Need leading zeros or
custom numbering?  Open **PowerShell** inside the folder (Shift + Right-click ÔûÂ *Open PowerShell
window here*) and run:  ```powershell $files = Get-ChildItem *.png | Sort-Object LastWriteTime
$count = 1 foreach ($f in $files) {     $new = "parts_{0:D3}.png" -f $count   # parts_001.png,
parts_002.png ÔÇª     Rename-Item $f.FullName $new     $count++ } ```  *Change `LastWriteTime` to
`Name` if you want alphabetical order; adjust `{0:D3}` to `D2` for two-digit numbering.*  ---  ###
Why the Explorer method is best for quick jobs  * **Zero learning curve** ÔÇô a single F2 rename. *
**Instant preview** ÔÇô if the result looks wrong, press **Ctrl + Z** to undo. * **No typing of paths
or scripts** ÔÇô minimal risk of typos.  Use PowerShell only when you need fancier patterns (zeros,
prefixes per sub-folder, etc.).

Git is a **distributed version control system**. At its core, Git lets you:  1. **Track Every
Change**      - Every time you ÔÇ£commit,ÔÇØ Git takes a snapshot of your entire project.      - You can
go back (ÔÇ£checkoutÔÇØ) to any previous snapshot if you break something.  2. **Branch & Experiment
Safely**      - Create a new branch to try out big changes (e.g. redesign your homepage) without
touching `main`.      - If it works, you merge it back. If it doesnÔÇÖt, you simply delete the
branchÔÇöno harm done.  3. **Collaborate & Share**      - Push your local commits to a remote (e.g.
GitHub) so teammates can pull them down, review, and contribute.      - Use pull/merge requests to
propose changes, have them code-reviewed, discuss, then merge.  4. **Backup & Sync Across Machines**
- Your entire history lives locally in `.git/` and can be mirrored on GitHub (or another host).
- Clone your repo on any new computer, `git pull` to get the latest code, and keep working.  5.
**Integrate with Tooling**      - CI/CD pipelines (tests, builds, deploys) can run automatically
whenever you push.      - VS Code (and most editors) have built-in Git UI for staging, diffing,
committing, branching.  ---  ### Quick Starter Checklist  1. **Install & Configure Git**
```bash    # Download & install from https://git-scm.com/downloads    git config --global user.name
"Your Name"    git config --global user.email you@example.com    ```  2. **Initialize or Clone**
```bash    # New project:    cd MatfordManufacturingWebsite    git init    git add .    git commit
-m "Initial commit"     # Or if you already pushed to GitHub:    git clone
https://github.com/you/MatfordManufacturingWebsite.git    cd MatfordManufacturingWebsite    ```  3.
**Make Changes & Commit**      ```bash    git checkout -b fancy-homepage    # create a feature
branch    # edit your files in VS CodeÔÇª    git add .    git commit -m "Add three alternating hero
sections"    ```  4. **Push & Open a PR**      ```bash    git push -u origin fancy-homepage    #
Then on GitHub: open a Pull Request from fancy-homepage ÔåÆ main    ```  5. **Merge & Clean Up**
- After review, merge your PR on GitHub.      - Locally:        ```bash      git checkout main
git pull                 # bring in the merged changes      git branch -d fancy-homepage      ```
---  ### Why Git Is Your Friend  - **Accident Recovery:** ÔÇ£Oops, I broke the contact page.ÔÇØ ÔåÆ `git
checkout HEAD~1 contact.html`   - **Clean Experimentation:** Try something crazy in its own branch,
toss it if it doesnÔÇÖt fly.   - **Team Workflow:** EveryoneÔÇÖs code is in one place, with a clear
history of who changed what and why.   - **Peace of Mind:** Your work is safely backed up on GitHub
(or another remote).  Once you get comfortable with the basic commitÔåÆbranchÔåÆmerge lifecycle, youÔÇÖll
wonder how you ever coded without it!

I've heard of websites or tools or apps that can basically take a snapshot of a website and copy the
codes, so you can then use it as a template for your own website. Is that possible to do for free
and what would be the most minimal way of doing it? And is there any copyright infringements that I
need to be aware of?

UNKNOWN:
YesÔÇöyou can absolutely grab a copy of a live siteÔÇÖs HTML/CSS/JS for your own learning or as a
starter, and there are completely free ways to do it. HereÔÇÖs a quick rundown of the two most minimal
approaches, and what you need to know about copyright:  ---  ## 1. ÔÇ£Save Page AsÔÇªÔÇØ in Your Browser
(Minimal, Zero-Install)  1. **Open** the page you want to copy in Chrome, Edge or Firefox.   2.
**Right-click** on the page (not on an image) and choose **Save AsÔÇª** (or **Save Page AsÔÇª**).   3.
In the dialog, select **ÔÇ£Webpage, CompleteÔÇØ**.      - This writes an `.html` file plus a folder of
all images, stylesheets and scripts that the browser automatically downloaded.   4. **Open** the
saved `.html` in your editor or VS CodeÔÇöyouÔÇÖll see the exact HTML, CSS and JS the browser saw.
**Pros:**   - Instant and no extra software.   - Good for grabbing a single page.    **Cons:**   -
WonÔÇÖt recursively follow links, so youÔÇÖll need to repeat for each page.   - Dynamic bits (API-driven
content, single-page apps) may not survive.  ---  ## 2. Command-Line Mirroring with `wget` or
HTTrack (For a Whole Site)  ### A) `wget` (built into most Linux/macOS; Windows via WSL or GnuWin32)
```bash # Mirror the entire site under site.local, staying on that domain: wget --mirror --convert-
links --adjust-extension --page-requisites \      --no-parent http://example.com/ ```  - `--mirror`
turns on recursion, time-stamping, etc.   - `--convert-links` makes the local copy navigable.   -
`--page-requisites` fetches images, CSS, JS.  ### B) HTTrack (GUI tool, free, cross-platform)  1.
Download & install from https://www.httrack.com/   2. Run **ÔÇ£WinHTTrack Website CopierÔÇØ** (Windows)
or Mac/Linux equivalent.   3. Enter your project name, the starting URL, default options are fine.
4. Click **Next/Finish**ÔÇöit will spider the entire site and save it locally.  **Pros:**   - Grabs
every page, rewrites links, downloads assets.   - Can throttle or limit depth to avoid over-
crawling.    **Cons:**   - Slower for large sites; youÔÇÖll need to configure exclusions if you only
want specific sections.  ---  ## Copyright & Licensing Considerations  - **HTML, CSS and images are
protected by copyright** by defaultÔÇöeven if theyÔÇÖre publicly viewable in your browser.   -
**Educational/fair-use** copying (just to see how something works on your local machine) is
generally low-risk.   - **Using the copied code in a live, public-facing site** without permission
can infringe the original authorÔÇÖs rights.   - **Safe practices**:     - **Inspect & learn**, then
**re-implement** with your own HTML/CSS.     - **Search for an explicit license**: some sites
publish their templates under MIT, GPL or Creative CommonsÔÇöif so, follow that license.     - **Use
free/open-source templates** from sites like HTML5 UP, BootstrapMade, or StartBootstrap, which
explicitly allow reuse.  ---  ### WhatÔÇÖs Easiest to Learn?  - **Browser ÔÇ£Save AsÔÇØ** is the absolute
simplestÔÇöno installs, zero config, perfect for grabbing one page and poking around.   - **HTTrack**
is the next step if you want a full multi-page clone; the GUI walks you through every option.  Pick
one, copy it down locally, and then open the files in VS Code. From there you can strip out or re-
write any bits you like. Let me know which approach youÔÇÖd like to try first, and I can walk you
through the exact steps!

I want to be able to dictate on Windows what I type. Is there a way to set that up so there's a
shortcut that I can press on the keyboard to enable dictation mode?

UNKNOWN:
Windows 10 and 11 actually ship with a built-in ÔÇ£voice typingÔÇØ (dictation) feature that you can
toggle on/off with a simple keyboard shortcut. HereÔÇÖs how to get it working:  ---  ## 1. Turn on
Online Speech Recognition  1. **Open Settings** ÔåÆ **Privacy & security** ÔåÆ **Speech**      - (In Win
10 itÔÇÖs **Settings** ÔåÆ **Privacy** ÔåÆ **Speech**.)   2. Toggle **ÔÇ£Online speech recognitionÔÇØ** (or
ÔÇ£Enable speech services and typing suggestionsÔÇØ) to **On**.   3. Make sure your microphone is
plugged in (or your headset/mic works) and set as the default input in **Settings** ÔåÆ **System** ÔåÆ
**Sound**.  ---  ## 2. Use the Windows + H Shortcut  1. Place your cursor in any text field
(Notepad, Word, your VS Code editor, a browser, etc.). 2. Press **Win Key + H**.      - YouÔÇÖll see a
small toolbar pop up at the top of the screen:        ![Voice Typing
Toolbar](https://i.imgur.com/PSk6ywq.png)   3. Start **speaking** ÔÇö Windows will transcribe your
words live into the text field.  > **Tip:** If nothing happens when you press Win + H, make sure
youÔÇÖve got **ÔÇ£Enable voice typingÔÇØ** turned on in **Settings** ÔåÆ **Time & Language** ÔåÆ **Speech**
(Windows 11) or **Settings** ÔåÆ **Privacy** ÔåÆ **Speech** (Windows 10).  ---  ## 3. (Optional) Launch
Windows Speech Recognition  Windows also includes a more fully-featured Speech Recognition system
that can be trained to your voice:  1. Open **Control Panel** ÔåÆ **Ease of Access** ÔåÆ **Speech
Recognition**.   2. Choose **ÔÇ£Start Speech RecognitionÔÇØ**.   3. Follow the microphone setup and
ÔÇ£train your computer to better understand you.ÔÇØ   4. Once running, you can toggle it on/off with a
desktop shortcut or pin it to your taskbar.  ---  ## 4. Custom Shortcut with AutoHotkey (Advanced)
If youÔÇÖd like a single-key toggle instead of Win + H:  1. **Install AutoHotkey** (free):
https://www.autohotkey.com/   2. Create a script (e.g. `dictate.ahk`) containing:    ```ahk    ;
Press F6 to toggle Windows dictation (Win+H)    F6::      Send, {LWin down}h{LWin up}    return
``` 3. Double-click that script to run.   4. Now pressing **F6** will simulate **Win + H** for you.
---  ### Why Win + H Is Easiest  - **No install required** beyond Windows itself.   - **Works
system-wide** in any text field.   - **Instant on/off** with one key combination.    If you have any
questions about microphone setup, training the speech engine, or using AutoHotkey, just let me know!

already)  1. **Open your VS Code integrated terminal** (or any terminal) in your project root
(`C:\MatfordManufacturingWebsite`).   2. Run:    ```bash    git init    ```    - **What this does**:
creates a hidden `.git/` folder that starts tracking changes in this directory.  ---  ## 2. Create
your first commit locally  1. **Tell Git which files to track**:    ```bash    git add .    ```    -
The dot means ÔÇ£add every new or changed file in this folder.ÔÇØ  2. **Commit those files**:    ```bash
git commit -m "Initial site setup: base templates, CSS and home hero"    ```    - **What this
does**: takes a snapshot of your current code and stores it in your local history with a message.
---  ## 3. Create a GitHub repository  1. Go to https://github.com and **log in** (or sign up). 2.
Click the **ÔÇ£+ÔÇØ** icon ÔåÆ **ÔÇ£New repositoryÔÇØ**. 3. Fill in:    - **Repository name**:
`MatfordManufacturingWebsite` (or whatever you like)    - **Description**: e.g. ÔÇ£Flask-based
manufacturing siteÔÇØ    - **Public** (so you can view it in a browser) or **Private** (only you)    -
**DonÔÇÖt** check ÔÇ£Initialize with READMEÔÇØ (you already have code). 4. Click **ÔÇ£Create repositoryÔÇØ**.
---  ## 4. Link your local repo to GitHub  Back in your terminal, GitHub will have shown you a
couple of commands under **ÔÇ£ÔÇªor push an existing repository from the command lineÔÇØ**. Run these
(adjusting the URL if yours is different):  ```bash git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-
username>/MatfordManufacturingWebsite.git git branch -M main           # rename your local branch to
'main' git push -u origin main      # push your commit to GitHub ```  - **What this does**:   -
`remote add origin ÔÇª` tells your local Git where on GitHub to send code.   - `git push -u origin
main` uploads your `main` branch to GitHub and remembers that connection for future pushes.  ---  ##
5. Verify it on GitHub  1. Navigate in your browser to      `https://github.com/<your-
username>/MatfordManufacturingWebsite`      ÔÇö you should see all your files listed. 2. Click on any
file to view its contents live.  ---  ## 6. Making changes & pushing updates  1. **Edit** your code
locally.   2. In terminal:    ```bash    git add .    git commit -m "Describe what you changed"
git push    ``` 3. Refresh your GitHub repo page ÔÇö your new commit will appear.  ---  ## 7. Rolling
back mistakes  - **View history**:   ```bash   git log --oneline   ```   shows all commits with
short IDs.  - **Revert a commit**:   ```bash   git revert <commit-id>   git push   ```   creates a
new ÔÇ£undoÔÇØ commit on top of your history.  - **Reset to an earlier state** (more drastic ÔÇô rewrites
history):   ```bash   git reset --hard <commit-id>   git push --force   ```   only use if you really
know what youÔÇÖre doing.  ---  ### Why do this?  - **Online backup**: your code lives safely on
GitHub.   - **Version history**: every commit is a restore point.   - **Collaboration (future-
proofing)**: easy for others (or another computer) to pull your code.    Once youÔÇÖve pushed, you can
clone this repo elsewhere:  ```bash git clone https://github.com/<your-
username>/MatfordManufacturingWebsite.git ```  ÔÇöand pick up right where you left off.  Enjoy a
worry-free smoke break! When youÔÇÖre back, pull your repo down on any machine and `pip install -r
requirements.txt` ÔåÆ `python app.py` ÔåÆ youÔÇÖll be live again in minutes.

</div>   </div>    <!-- your nav goes here -->   <nav>     ÔÇª   </nav> </header> ```  ### B) Tweak
the CSS  Open **static/css/style.css** andÔÇª  1. **After** your `.header-tiles` / `.header-tiles

display: flex;      gap: 1rem;      flex-wrap: wrap;      justify-content: center;      align-items:
center;    }     /* Mobile: stack logo above parts */    @media (max-width: 768px) {      .header-
tiles {        display: flex;        flex-direction: column;        align-items: center;        gap:
0.5rem;        padding: 1rem 0;      }      /* logo on top stays full width */      .logo {
order: 0;        margin-bottom: 1rem;      }      /* tiles-row becomes the second row */

sits on top with all parts in a neat row underneath.  ---  ## 2) Add a real hamburger toggle  Your
menu button wasnÔÇÖt wired up, so letÔÇÖs correct that.  ### A) Add the menu icon to your header  In
**templates/base.html**, right before your `<nav>ÔÇª</nav>`, insert:  ```html   <!-- hamburger icon

### B) Style it  In **static/css/style.css**, add:  ```css /* hide by default, only show on mobile

HereÔÇÖs one way to get exactly what youÔÇÖre describing ÔÇö a solid blue panel on the left, fading
smoothly into a full-bleed machine-photo on the right, with your Matford logo pinned top-left and
the image pinned top-right, all stretching to whatever the viewport width is.  ---  ### 1. HTML
Wrap your header/logo area in a single ÔÇ£bannerÔÇØ element:  ```html <header class="header-banner">
<div class="banner-logo">     <img src="{{ url_for('static', filename='images/matford-logo.png') }}"
alt="Matford Manufacturing">   </div>   <!-- if you want any nav/toggle in here you can add it too
--> </header> ```  ---  ### 2. CSS  ```css /* 1) Base banner setup */ .header-banner {   position:
relative;   display: flex;   justify-content: space-between; /* logo left, photo-right */   align-
items: flex-start;        /* tweak as you like */   width: 100vw;   height: 200px;
/* or whatever banner height you want */   overflow: hidden;      /* 2) multiple backgrounds:
- top layer = fade from solid blue ÔåÆ transparent      - bottom layer = your chuck photo, anchored
right */   background:     linear-gradient(       to right,       var(--blue) 0%,       var(--blue)
50%,       rgba(10,61,98,0) 100%     ),     url('/static/images/mori-chuck-closeup.jpg') no-repeat
right center;   background-size:     200% 100%,   /* make the gradient twice as wide so it can fade
out */     cover;       /* scale your machine-photo to cover the banner */ }  /* 3) Logo sizing /
positioning */ .header-banner .banner-logo img {   max-height: 150px;  /* so it never overruns your
banner */   width: auto;   margin: 1rem;       /* breathing room */   z-index: 1;         /* above
the gradient/photo */ }  /* 4) Make it responsive */ @media (max-width: 768px) {   .header-banner {
height: 140px;     background:       linear-gradient(         to bottom,         var(--blue) 0%,
var(--blue) 50%,         rgba(10,61,98,0) 100%       ),       url('/static/images/mori-chuck-
closeup.jpg') no-repeat center bottom;     background-size:       100% 200%,       cover;     flex-
direction: column;     justify-content: flex-start;   }   .header-banner .banner-logo {     margin-
bottom: 1rem;   } } ```  ---  #### How this works  1. **Multiple backgrounds**      CSS lets you
stack as many backgrounds as you like.      - **Top layer** is a `linear-gradient` from solid blue
(`var(--blue)`) on the left to transparent on the right.      - **Bottom layer** is your machine-
photo, anchored to the right edge.  2. **Sizing & positioning**      - `background-size: 200% 100%`
on the gradient makes the fade run only across the right half of the banner (so the left stays a
solid block of blue).      - `background-size: cover` on the photo makes it fill the banner area,
cropping where necessary.  3. **Flex layout**      We use `display: flex; justify-content: space-
between` so that the logo sits flush left and, if you ever add another element (say a nav toggle) it
could sit flush right ÔÇö all perfectly responsive.  4. **Responsive tweak**      In narrow/mobile
views, we switch the fade to go **topÔåÆbottom** (so youÔÇÖll have a solid blue bar at the top that
fades down into the image), and stack your logo above the photo.  ---  Just swap in your actual
image filename (`mori-chuck-closeup.jpg` above) and adjust the color stops (50% fade point, heights,
margins) to taste. That should give you a clean, fluid ÔÇ£solid blue into machine-shotÔÇØ banner with
your logo pinned left and the photo pinned right at all widths.

I seem to have broken the website, how do I restore it through VS Code, the fastest way to restore
my Git?

UNKNOWN:
The quickest way to get yourself back to a known-good state is to throw away whateverÔÇÖs in your
working tree and reset to the last commit (or whatever commit you know was working). You can do that
straight from VS CodeÔÇÖs UI or from the integrated terminal.  ---  ## Option A ÔÇô VS Code UI (no
terminal required)  1. Open the **Source Control** panel (click the branch icon on the left
sidebar).   2. At the top youÔÇÖll see ÔÇ£ChangesÔÇØ listed. Click the **ellipsis** (ÔÇª) menu there and
choose **Discard All Changes**.      - That will revert every modified file back to whateverÔÇÖs in
your **HEAD** commit.   3. If youÔÇÖve *also* staged some changes, click the ÔÇ£Staged ChangesÔÇØ header,
ellipsis (ÔÇª) ÔåÆ **Discard All Staged Changes**.    Once thatÔÇÖs done, your entire workspace is back to
exactly what was last committed.  ---  ## Option B ÔÇô Git commands in the terminal  If youÔÇÖre
comfortable in the terminal, these two commands will do the same thing:  1. **Throw away all local
edits** (both staged and unstaged):    ```bash    git restore --source=HEAD --staged --worktree .
``` 2. **If you want to reset even your HEAD** (say you accidentally moved it), or bring yourself
back to the *remote* state:    ```bash    git fetch origin    git reset --hard origin/main    ```
ÔÇô `git fetch` grabs the latest from GitHub      ÔÇô `git reset --hard origin/main` moves your local
branch pointer to match the remote and wipes out any local edits  ---  ### Safety first  -
**Uncommitted** changes you havenÔÇÖt pushed yet will be lost forever when you discard them.   - If
you think some edits might be worth keeping, stash them first:   ```bash   git stash push -m "WIP ÔÇô
broken site"   ```   then reset, and you can always recover them later with `git stash pop`.  ---
Once youÔÇÖre back at a clean state, re-run your Flask server:  ```bash # activate your venvÔÇª # on
Windows PowerShell .\venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1  # then python -m flask run ```  Your site should now
look exactly like it did at your last commit. Let me know if any of those steps throws an error!

you want to commit must appear under **ÔÇ£Staged ChangesÔÇØ**. | | 2 | **Empty or duplicate commit
message?** | VS Code wonÔÇÖt commit with a blank message.<br>In the little text box at the top of
*Source Control*, type something like:<br>`feat: enlarge banner + logo size` and hit **Ctrl +

| In the bottom-left status bar the branch name should read `main*` (or `main`).<br>If it shows
`(HEAD)` or a different branch, run:<br>`git switch main` | | 5 | **Credentials prompt hidden?** |
Sometimes Windows pops an auth dialog **behind** VS Code. Alt-Tab and check.<br>If you use HTTPS & a
PAT, make sure the credential helper has it saved. | | 6 | **Long-running post-commit hook?** |
Rare, but run a commit from the terminal to see verbose output:<br>`git commit -m "temp" && git

Yes ÔÇö CSS now lets us size an element *fluidly* with `clamp( min , ideal , max )`.   That one line
tells the browser:  * **Grow** the logo in proportion to the viewport (`vw`) so it always ÔÇ£feelsÔÇØ
the same size.   * **Never** shrink below a readable minimum.   * **Never** blow up past a sensible
cap on big monitors.  ---  ### 1 ´©ÅÔâú Replace the two existing logo-size rules  1. **Open
`static/css/style.css`.**   2. Delete the *desktop* rule (`.banner-logo img { max-height: ÔÇª }`) and
the *mobile* rule you just added.   3. Paste this single rule *once* (just below the `.banner-logo
img { ÔÇª } comment is fine):  ```css /* fluid logo ÔÇô grows with viewport, but stays between 120 px Ôåö
320 px */ .banner-logo img{     height: clamp(120px , 14vw , 320px);     width:  auto; } ```  **What
that means**  * `14vw` = ÔÇ£14 % of the viewport widthÔÇØ ÔÇô thatÔÇÖs the *ideal* size.   * `clamp()` wonÔÇÖt
let it go below `120 px` (small phones) or above `320 px` (huge desktop).  You no longer need
separate desktop / mobile logo rules; one clamp handles everything.  ---  ### 2 ´©ÅÔâú (Optional) keep
the banner height in step  If youÔÇÖd like the blue mast-head itself to expand a bit when the logo
gets bigger, swap its fixed height for another `clamp()`:  ```css .masthead{     position: relative;
width: 100%;     min-height: clamp(240px , 28vw , 400px);  /* Ôåô was 345px */     display: flex;
align-items: center;     background:         linear-gradient(to right,
rgba(10,61,98,.9),             rgba(10,61,98,.9) 0%,             rgba(10,61,98,.0) 100%),
url('/static/images/Mori_home_bg.jpg') center/cover no-repeat;     color: #fff; } ```  *Now the
banner can range from 240 px on small screens up to 400 px on a wide desktop, always keeping good
proportions.*  ---  ### 3 ´©ÅÔâú Save ÔåÆ refresh  Because FlaskÔÇÖs dev server watches your files, as soon
as you save **style.css** your browser should live-reload. Test it:  * drag the responsive viewport
handle (or press `Ctrl + Shift + M` in Chrome/Edge dev-tools)   * watch the logo smoothly scale
while never getting absurdly large or tiny.  Tweak the three numbers inside each `clamp()` until it
feels perfect for your design.  Let me know if you prefer a different range or need anything else

Here are three **no-cost, ÔÇ£one-click-ishÔÇØ** routes you can use to turn that jagged PNG into a crisp,
scalable logo. All of them run on Windows 11 and none of them require Photoshop or paid AI services.
---  ## 1 Ôû¬ Convert it to vector with **Inkscape** (best quality, totally free)  | ÔÇ╝´©Å Why vector? |
Once the artwork is SVG (curves, not pixels) it will render razor-sharp at any sizeÔÇöfrom a favicon
to a wall bannerÔÇöwithout ever getting jaggy again. | |---|---|  ### Steps  1. **Install Inkscape**
*Download from* <https://inkscape.org> (*Open Source, free*).  2. **Open your PNG**      `File Ôû©
Import ÔÇª` ÔåÆ pick the logo.  3. **Trace Bitmap**      `Path Ôû© Trace BitmapÔÇª`      *Settings that work
well on a white-on-transparent logo*      * Mode : *Brightness cutoff*      * Threshold :
**0.80ÔÇô0.90**      * ÔÜÖ´©Å Check **ÔÇ£Remove backgroundÔÇØ**      * Click **OK** ÔåÆ a new, vector version
appears on top of the original.  4. **Delete the old pixel image** (select, Delete).  5. **Save as
SVG**      `File Ôû© Save asÔÇª` ÔåÆ `matford_logo.svg`.  6. **Export a fresh PNG for the site**
`File Ôû© Export Ôû© PNG ImageÔÇª`      *Set width 2000 px* (plenty for retina-screens) ÔåÆ **Export**.
Drop the exported PNG (or the SVG if all your browsers/users support it) into `static/images/` and
youÔÇÖre doneÔÇöno more pixelated edges.  ---  ## 2 Ôû¬ Use a free AI upscaler (**Upscayl** desktop app)
If you donÔÇÖt want to mess with vectors you can simply upscale & denoise the bitmap.  1. **Install
Upscayl** ÔÇô <https://upscayl.org> (MIT-licensed desktop app).   2. Open the PNG, choose the **ÔÇ£Line
ArtÔÇØ** model.   3. Upscale ├ù4 or ├ù8; output PNG.      *It removes ringing and staircase artefacts
very well.*  Drop the up-scaled file into your project; your CSS clamp rule will automatically down-
scale it in the browser, but because the source has far more pixels the edges look smooth.  ---  ##
3 Ôû¬ Quick-and-dirty online cleanup (no install)  1. Go to **vectorizer.ai** or **vectormagic.com**
(both have free basic output).   2. Upload the PNG ÔåÆ choose ÔÇ£logo / flat shapesÔÇØ.   3. Download the
SVG or high-res PNG.  ---  ### Which should I pick?  | Need | Best Choice | |------|-------------| |
Perfect edge quality & infinite scalability | **Inkscape + Trace Bitmap** | | ÔÇ£Good enoughÔÇØ in 60
seconds | Online vectorizer | | Large, smooth bitmap without learning curves | **Upscayl** |  Once

Below are concrete, small-scope tweaks that make the content area ÔÇ£popÔÇØ without fighting the
navy-/red brand youÔÇÖve begun.  Nothing here requires a redesignÔÇöyou can layer each idea into
ÔÇïstatic/css/style.cssÔÇï and your templates.  ---  ### 1.  Raise overall contrast & legibility   | Why
| Quick CSS you can paste | What youÔÇÖll notice |
|-----|------------------------|--------------------| | **Text-on-blue is just under WCAG AAA
contrast.** Bumping it to a near-white instantly lifts clarity.  ¯êÇcite¯êéturn0news19¯êü |```css
body{color:#f4f8ff;} /* instead of #fff */```| Paragraphs feel ÔÇ£lit-upÔÇØ; visitors donÔÇÖt need to
squint when the hero image is bright. | | **Heading hierarchy.** Give `h2ÔÇôh4` a lighter tint so the
white H1 dominates. |```css h2{color:#c8e2ff} h3{color:#a5cfff}```| The eye jumps first to the big
pitch, then gracefully flows downward. |  ---  ### 2.  Micro-drop-shadow on the content card   If
you ever place text directly on imagery (e.g., next hero sections), add a 2-line utility:  ```css
.text-on-img{    text-shadow:0 1px 3px rgba(0,0,0,.65); } ``` Apply with `class="text-on-img"` where
needed. It boosts legibility while keeping white type.  ---  ### 3.  Slim, darker nav bar   You
already shortened the padding.  To deepen colour *only* on the bar (not the page body), keep the
brand hue but slide it ~10 % toward black:  ```css nav{    background:#062d57;   /* current is
#0d3262 ÔÇô this adds subtle depth */    padding:4px 0;        /* stays slim */    box-shadow:0 2px
4px rgba(0,0,0,.15); /* soft separation from hero */ } ```  ---  ### 4.  Button refinements   **A.
Accent under-glow when hovered** ÔÇô draws the cursor back to CTAs without animation overload.  ```css
.btn-primary:hover{    box-shadow:0 4px 12px rgba(208,43,43,.35); /* brandÔÇôtinted glow */
transform:translateY(-1px); } .btn-primary{transition:box-shadow .2s,transform .2s;} ```  **B.
Consistent pill radius** ÔÇô your nav links already use `4 px`; reuse on the CTA for cohesion.
```css .btn-primary{border-radius:4px;} ```  ---  ### 5.  Typography polish   * **Webfont pairing**
ÔÇô Inter pairs nicely with *DM Sans* (free on Google Fonts) for headings:    ```html <link
href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=DM+Sans:wght@700&display=swap" rel="stylesheet"> ```
```css h1,h2{font-family:"DM Sans",Inter,Helvetica,sans-serif;} ``` DM SansÔÇÖ wide apertures stay
readable on small screens. ¯êÇcite¯êéturn0search6¯êü    * **Letter-spacing inside the CTA** ÔÇô long label,
so add a hair of tracking:   ```css .btn-primary{letter-spacing:.02em;} ```  ---  ### 6.  Hero &
body balance   A common engineering-site trick is a *very gentle* radial overlay that keeps focus on
centre text and lets edges fade into navy:  ```css .masthead::before{    content:'';
position:absolute;inset:0;    background:radial-gradient(circle at center,
rgba(10,61,98,0) 40%,               rgba(10,61,98,.65) 100%);    pointer-events:none; } ``` You keep
the photo but stop it from fighting the logo or CTA on ultra-wide monitors.  ---  ### 7.  Spacing
rhythm with ÔÇ£8-pt gridÔÇØ   Cement a predictable cadence (4 px, 8 px, 16 pxÔÇª) for vertical space so
nothing reads ÔÇ£random.ÔÇØ Example:  ```css section{padding:64px 0;}      /* 8├ù8 */ section +
section{margin-top:0;} /* rely on padding instead */ p{margin:0 0 16px;} ``` This alone makes a site
feel designed (not templated). ¯êÇcite¯êéturn0search8¯êü  ---  #### Colour-scheme cheat sheet (derived
from your navy + red) | Token | Hex | Use | |-------|-----|-----| | `--blue-dk` | #062d57 | nav bar,
footers | | `--blue` | #0a3d62 | hero overlay, big backgrounds | | `--blue-lt` | #2774bb | link
hovers, subtle borders | | `--red` | #d02b2b | primary CTA | | `--red-dk` | #b31f1f | CTA hover
shadow | | `--grey-bg` | #f7f9fc | light sections / cards |  Declare them at the top of CSS for easy
reuse:  ```css :root{   --blue-dk:#062d57;--blue:#0a3d62;--blue-lt:#2774bb;   --red:#d02b2b;--red-
dk:#b31f1f;--grey-bg:#f7f9fc; } ```  ---  ### Next steps you can pick & choose  1. **Try the text-

`img:'part1.png'` line looks white**     VS CodeÔÇÖs Jinja / HTML grammar does not ÔÇ£knowÔÇØ that the
key/value pairs between `{% set heroes = [ ÔÇª ] %}` are JavaScript-style objects, so it colours
everything inside that block as plain text. The template engine (Jinja) will still read the list
correctly because:    ```jinja   {% set heroes = [       { img:'part1.png', title:'text', lines:[ÔÇª]
},       ÔÇª   ] %}   ```    * the braces `{ ÔÇª }`, colons `:`, and quotes are exactly what Jinja
expects;     * the surrounding `{% ÔÇª %}` tells Jinja to treat it as Python-style data (lists /
dicts).  * **When would it be wrong?**     Only if you accidentally omitted a quote or a comma, e.g.
`img:part1.png` or left a trailing comma after the last object. Otherwise the colour does not
matter.  ---  ### Quick sanity-check  1. Keep each hero object on one ÔÇ£logicalÔÇØ level:  ```jinja {

### Why you only see blue ÔÇ£tilesÔÇØ  What you are seeing is the **`<article class="hero-card">`**
element itself (its darkÔÇôblue background), but the image inside it is collapsing to **0 px** tall,
so no picture or copy ever shows.   There are two independent causes:  | line(s) | problem | quick
fix | |---------|---------|-----------| | **162ÔÇô163** in **styles.css** ÔåÆ `.hero-card img` |
`height:100%` is being inherited from a *previous* version of the rule; because a card has no
intrinsic height, 100 % = 0 px. | change to `height:auto;` (or delete the line). | | **176ÔÇô185** in
**styles.css** ÔåÆ `.hero-copy` | The text panel is set `position:absolute; right:0; bottom:0;
width:48%`. That is fine, **but** you removed the `background` colour (or set it to
fullyÔÇôtransparent #063b...92). The panel is there ÔÇö you just cannot read white text on darkÔÇôblue. |
reinstate a slightly translucent dark background, e.g. `background:rgba(6,58,89,.92);` |  Once the
image has a real height and the copy has a readable backdrop, every card will look like the mock-up.
---  ## Step-by-step fix  1. **Open `static/css/style.css`**  2. **Find the current *LANDSCAPE
MULTI-HERO* block**      (starts with `/* ----  LANDSCAPE MULTI-HERO  ---- */`)  3. **Edit just
three rules**  ```css /* ------------------ 1. the card itself ------------------ */ .hero-card{
/* leave everything elseÔÇª */     flex:1 1 280px;      /* min-width 280 px */     max-width:340px;
/* stays readable on XL screens */     /* Ôåô give the card an intrinsic height so % works   */
--h:240px;           /* tweak here if you want taller */     min-height:var(--h); }  /*
------------------ 2. the big photo ------------------ */ .hero-card img{     width:100%;
height:auto;         /* <---  FIX  */     object-fit:contain;  /* whole part visible */
display:block;     margin-bottom:1rem; }  /* ------------------ 3. the copy panel ------------------
*/ .hero-copy{     position:absolute;     right:0; bottom:0;     width:48%;
background:rgba(6,58,89,.92);   /*  brand dark-blue + slight alpha  */     color:#fff;
padding:1.25rem 1.5rem;     backdrop-filter:blur(2px); } ```  4. **Save Ô×£ hard-refresh the browser**
(`Ctrl + Shift + R`)  You should now see  * five landscape cards in one neat row on desktop * each
card shows its PNG, title and bullet list * when the viewport narrows the row wraps 3 + 2, then 2 +
2 + 1, always centred.  ---  ### Extra (optional) tweaks  * **Card height** ÔÇô change `--h:240px` in
`.hero-card`. * **Photo crop** ÔÇô swap `object-fit:contain` ÔåÆ `cover` if youÔÇÖd rather fill the frame
(may crop edges). * **Copy width** ÔÇô adjust `width:48%` (e.g. 40 % on very busy photos). * **Hover
effect** ÔÇô keep `transform:translateY(-6px)` or delete if you do not want the lift.  ---  That is
all you need to get the heroes fully visible again.   Give it a try and let me know how it looks!

LetÔÇÖs make three key tweaks so your hero always scales nicely:  1. **Lock the overall aspect ratio**
(so it never becomes a giant bar or square).   2. **Make the image fully responsive** but capped so
it never ÔÇ£blows upÔÇØ or ÔÇ£squashes.ÔÇØ   3. **Use fluid typography** (via `clamp()`) so your
headings/text shrink gracefully.  ---  ### 1) Give the hero a fixed aspect-ratio  Right at the top
of your `.solo-hero` rule add:  ```css .solo-hero {   /* keep a nice widescreen shape (16:9) */
aspect-ratio: 16 / 9;   display: grid;   grid-template-columns: 20% 80%;   gap: 1rem;   padding:
1.2rem 0.8rem;   align-items: center;   background-color: var(--hero-bg);   border-radius: 12px;
margin: 2rem auto;   max-width: 1200px; } ```  > **Why?**   > The `aspect-ratio` property forces the
container to maintain a 16:9 shape.  On narrow screens itÔÇÖll shrink in height rather than stretch
wider.  ---  ### 2) Make your image truly responsive  Replace your old image rule with:  ```css /*
image container */ .solo-hero_image {   /* ensure this cell participates in the aspect-ratio */
display: flex;   align-items: center;   justify-content: center;   overflow: hidden; }  /* the img
itself */ .solo-hero_image img {   /* fill the column but keep its intrinsic ratio */   width: 100%;
height: auto;   object-fit: contain;   object-position: center;   max-height: 100%; /* never taller
than the 16/9 box */      /* animation */   opacity: 0;   transform: translateY(20px);   animation:
fadeInUp 0.8s ease-out forwards; } ```  > **Why?**   > - `height: auto` + `max-height: 100%`
prevents distortion on tall or narrow screens.   > - Wrapping it in a flex container ensures it
stays centered.  ---  ### 3) Fluid typography for your copy  Lower down, adjust your hero heading
and paragraph:  ```css /* copy column */ .solo-hero_copy {   opacity: 0;   transform:
translateY(20px);   animation: fadeInUp 0.8s ease-out forwards;   animation-delay: 0.4s; }  /* fluid
heading & text */ .solo-hero_copy h2 {   font-size: clamp(1.2rem, 2.5vw, 2rem);   margin-bottom:
0.5rem; } .solo-hero_copy p {   font-size: clamp(0.9rem, 1.8vw, 1.1rem);   line-height: 1.4; } ```
> **Why?**   > - `clamp(min, preferred, max)` makes your text shrink on small screens but never too
small.  ---  ### 4) Tweak the mobile breakpoint  Finally, refine your existing mobile media-query:

Below is an end-to-end ÔÇ£recipeÔÇØ that keeps everything inside your existing **Flask** project and
requirements workflow.  ---  ## 1. Add the libraries to **requirements.txt**  ```text # ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ video
handling ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ youtube-dl==2021.12.17   # the classic, still works for most URLs ffmpeg-python==0.2.0
# lightweight wrapper ÔÇô needs system ffmpeg ```  *If you already use **pip-tools** or Poetry, add
the two lines to the proper file instead.*  > **System FFmpeg**   > `ffmpeg-python` only calls your
machineÔÇÖs `ffmpeg` binary.   > ÔÇó Mac ÔåÆ `brew install ffmpeg`   > ÔÇó Ubuntu ÔåÆ `sudo apt install
ffmpeg`   > ÔÇó Windows ÔåÆ download the static build ÔåÆ add `ffmpeg.exe` to *PATH*.  ---  ## 2. Tiny
helper script: *download + trim*  Create **scripts/grab_video.py**  ```python import youtube_dl
import ffmpeg import os, sys, pathlib  # ---------- config ---------- YOUTUBE_URL =
"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XXXXXXXXXXX"  # <- YOUR link OUT_DIR     =
pathlib.Path(__file__).resolve().parents[1] / "static" / "videos" RAW_MP4     = OUT_DIR /
"raw_download.mp4" TRIMMED_MP4 = OUT_DIR / "hero_loop.mp4" START_S     = 3          # seconds where
clip starts DURATION_S  = 12         # seconds to keep # ----------------------------
OUT_DIR.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)  ydl_opts = {     "format": "best[ext=mp4]/best",
"outtmpl": str(RAW_MP4),     "quiet": True, }  print("ÔûÂ DownloadingÔÇª") with
youtube_dl.YoutubeDL(ydl_opts) as ydl:     ydl.download([YOUTUBE_URL])  print("Ô£é TrimmingÔÇª") (
ffmpeg     .input(str(RAW_MP4), ss=START_S, t=DURATION_S)     .output(str(TRIMMED_MP4),
vcodec="libx264", acodec="aac", movflags="+faststart", preset="veryfast", video_bitrate="1500k",
audio_bitrate="128k")     .overwrite_output()     .run(quiet=True) )  RAW_MP4.unlink()            #
remove temp print(f"Ô£à Saved ÔåÆ {TRIMMED_MP4}") ```  Run once:  ```bash python scripts/grab_video.py
```  You end up with `static/videos/hero_loop.mp4` (Ôëê 2ÔÇô3 MB).  *(If you change the clip later, just
rerun.)*  ---  ## 3. Drop the **HTML** snippet in *home.html*  ```html <!-- ====== HERO VIDEO STRIP
====== --> <section class="video-hero">   <video autoplay muted loop playsinline          src="{{
url_for('static', filename='videos/hero_loop.mp4') }}">   </video>   <!-- optional overlay copy -->
<div class="v-caption">       <h2>Micro-second cycle times</h2>   </div> </section> ```  Place it
**just below** the mast-head banner and above your existing content.  ---  ## 4. Add 25 lines of CSS
(bottom of *style.css*)  ```css /* ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ Responsive full-width video hero ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ */ .video-hero {
position: relative;   width: 100%;   height: clamp(240px, 38vw, 480px);   /* ~40 % of viewport width
*/   overflow: hidden; }  .video-hero video {   position: absolute;   top: 50%; left: 50%;   min-
width: 100%;            /* always cover */   min-height: 100%;   transform: translate(-50%, -50%);
object-fit: cover;   pointer-events: none;       /* no pause / right-click */ }  .v-caption {
position: absolute;   right: 2rem; bottom: 1.5rem;      /* bottom-right */   background:
rgba(0,0,0,.50);   padding: .8rem 1.2rem;   border-radius: 6px;   color: #fff;   font-family:
'Oswald', sans-serif;   letter-spacing: .5px;   font-size: clamp(1.25rem, 2vw + .5rem, 2rem); } ```
*Hero shrinks automatically on narrow screens; height scales with viewport width.*  ---  ## 5. Wire
the **/mori_machines** page to reuse the same video (optional)  ```python @app.route("/mori-
machines") def mori_machines():     return render_template("mori_machines.html",
hero_video="videos/hero_loop.mp4") ```  Inside *mori_machines.html*:  ```html <video autoplay muted
loop playsinline        src="{{ url_for('static', filename=hero_video) }}"></video> ```  ---  ## 6.
Commit & push  ```bash git add requirements.txt scripts/ static/videos/ style.css
templates/home.html git commit -m "Embed auto-loop hero video" git push ```  ---  ### Three pro-tips
automatically baked in  1. **`playsinline` + `muted`** ÔåÆ video autoplays even on iOS (Safari blocks
audio-on-load otherwise).   2. **`object-fit: cover`** keeps aspect-ratio while covering the strip,
no black bars.   3. **`movflags +faststart`** in FFmpeg writes the moov atom first ÔåÆ video begins
playing before itÔÇÖs fully downloaded.  ---  > **Copyright reminder**   > Make sure you have the
creatorÔÇÖs permission (or the clip is licensed for reuse). ÔÇ£DL + embedÔÇØ is fine for internal demos,
but public usage may require explicit rights.  ThatÔÇÖs it ÔÇö refresh the homepage and youÔÇÖll see a
clean, un-pausable, looping video stretching edge-to-edge above the fold.

any variable you invent called `ffmpeg`.*   In the screenshot you created a **new system variable**

'ffmpeg' is not recognized ÔÇª ```  ---  ## Fix in three clicks  1. **Open the same Environment-
Variables window again**      (Start Ôû║ *Environment Variables* Ôû║ *System variables* section).  2.
**Edit the existing ÔÇ£PathÔÇØ entry**       * Select **Path** (the one inside *System variables*).
* Click **EditÔÇª**      * Click **New** and paste the real folder that contains `ffmpeg.exe`, e.g.
```      C:\FFMpeg\bin      ```    * Make sure there are **no quotes**, no extra back-slashes, and
it points to the folder that actually contains the exe.  3. **OK ÔåÆ OK ÔåÆ OK** to close every dialog.
---  ## Apply the new PATH  *Close every terminal / VS Code integrated shell you had open.*   Open a
brand-new PowerShell (or CMD) window **after** the change:  ```powershell ffmpeg -version ```  You
should now get something like:  ``` ffmpeg version 6.0-full_build-www.gyan.dev ÔÇª  built with gcc
13.2 ÔÇª ```  That single line proves PATH is working; the Python wrapper will pick it up
automatically.  ---  ### Still not recognised?  | Symptom | What to check |
|---------|---------------| | *ÔÇ£not recognisedÔÇØ* after you followed the steps | The new shell must
inherit the new PATH. Make sure you actually closed VS CodeÔÇÖs terminal pane and re-opened it, or
open a normal Windows Terminal outside of VS Code. | | Typo in folder name | `C:\FFMpeg\bin` and
`C:\ffmpeg\bin` are **different**; use the exact path as displayed in File ExplorerÔÇÖs address bar. |
| Wrong level in the tree | Add the *bin* folder itself, not the parent folder. The line must end
with `\bin`. | | Multiple FFmpeg versions | If you installed FFmpeg elsewhere earlier, remove those
old entries from Path so Windows doesnÔÇÖt find the wrong exe first. |  Once `ffmpeg -version` works,
re-activate your virtual-environment (`.\venv\Scripts\Activate`) and repeat the quick end-to-end
test:  ```powershell python scripts\grab_video.py ```  Everything should now run without ÔÇ£ffmpeg not
foundÔÇØ errors, and you can continue embedding your looped video in Flask.

Below is a quick faultÔÇôtree that will catch **every** reason Windows still says     `ffmpeg : The
term 'ffmpeg' is not recognized ÔÇª`.  ---  ## 0  What your screenshot shows  * **Good** ÔÇô you un-
zipped into `C:\FFMpeg\bin` and that folder really contains `ffmpeg.exe`. * **Wrong place** ÔÇô you
created a **new variable called `ffmpeg`** and gave it the value `C:\ffmpeg\bin`.     Windows does
**not** search every variable ÔÇô it only searches the **Path** list.  ---  ## 1  Put the folder in
*Path* (not in a new variable)  1. **System Properties Ôû© Advanced Ôû© Environment VariablesÔÇª**   2. In
the bottom pane (ÔÇ£System variablesÔÇØ) **scroll** until you see Ôû▓ **Path** Ôû▓   3. Select **Path Ôû©
EditÔÇª**   4. **New** Ôû© paste    ``` C:\ffmpeg\bin ```  5. *Leave* the other entry called
`ffmpeg=C:\ffmpeg\bin` there or delete it ÔÇô it no longer matters.   6. **OK ÔåÆ OK ÔåÆ OK**  ---  ## 2
Restart every program that was already open  * The Path is copied into every running process **only
at launch time**.     You must close & reopen:   * VS Code (the whole window, not just the terminal)
* Any PowerShell / CMD windows * Quick test in a fresh **Win + R ÔåÆ cmd ÔåÆ `where ffmpeg`**     * Good
ÔåÆ it prints `C:\ffmpeg\bin\ffmpeg.exe`     * Bad ÔåÆ ÔÇ£INFO: Could not find files ÔÇªÔÇØ ÔåÆ the Path entry
is still wrong.  ---  ## 3  If `where ffmpeg` still fails, one of these is true  | Check | How to
verify | Fix | |-------|---------------|-----| | **Folder typo** | Explorer ÔåÆ paste `C:\ffmpeg\bin`
in the address bar. | Correct the Path entry. | | **File typo / missing** | Does `ffmpeg.exe` exist
in that folder? | Re-extract the ZIP, or copy the file. | | **Extra quotes / space** | In Path
editor make sure the entry is exactly <br>`C:\ffmpeg\bin` (no quotes, no trailing `\`). | Re-edit. |
| **Not really a new session** | Open **Start Ôû© Windows Terminal** and run `where ffmpeg`. | Close
VS Code, reopen after Path works in a normal terminal. | | **Using PowerShell alias** | In
PowerShell run <br>`Get-Command ffmpeg` | Nothing should be returned except the exe. If it shows a
wrong alias, remove it from profile. | | **32-bit / ARM build on 32-bit PowerShell** | `ffmpeg.exe`
should still run; rarely an AV blocks it. | Try double-clicking exe; if Windows blocks, unblock in
file properties. |  ---  ## 4  When `where ffmpeg` works, VS Code will work too  ```powershell >
where ffmpeg C:\ffmpeg\bin\ffmpeg.exe  > ffmpeg -version ffmpeg version 7.0.1-full_build ÔÇª ```  Now
you can proceed with:  ```powershell cd static\video ffmpeg -i "<video-URL>" -c copy dmg_full.mp4
```  and the trimming / embedding steps from the previous message.  ---  ### Quick sanity script
(optional)  Paste into any terminal to display the exact entry VS Code sees:  ```powershell echo
"`nCURRENT PATH:"; $env:Path -split ';' | ? {$_ -match 'ffmpeg'} | % { "  $_" } where ffmpeg ```
You should see `C:\ffmpeg\bin` in the list, and `where ffmpeg` must return the exe path. If not, the
problem is **still** step 1 or step 2.  Follow this checklist and ffmpeg will be callable from every
shell ÔÇô including the one inside VS Code ÔÇô in under five minutes.

|-------------|--------------------|---------------------| |
`/video/750000/init.mp4`<br>`/video/1500000/init.mp4` | *Initialization fragment* (contains only
codec headers) | No real frames, so ffmpeg canÔÇÖt guess details | | `/audio/120000/init.mp4` | Audio-
only init fragment | Same problem + you asked for video codec copy |  ---  ## Fix: fetch the **whole

### Why you got a **53-second** clip instead of a 7-second one  ```powershell ffmpeg -ss 00:00:46 -t
00:00:53 -i .\static\video\nlx_src.mp4 ÔÇª ```  * `-ss 00:00:46` ÔåÆ **seek** to 00:46 in the source ÔÇô
correct.   * `-t 00:00:53`   ÔåÆ **tell FFmpeg to keep 53 seconds** of video after that seek.  Because
`-t` means *duration*, not *end-time*, FFmpeg dutifully exported 46 s ÔåÆ (46 + 53) = 99 s (your whole
file ends at 00:53, so you got ~53 s).  ---  ## Two ways to cut **exactly 7 s**  | Goal | Option |
Example | |------|--------|---------| | duration based | use `-t 7` | `-ss 00:00:46 -t 7` | | ÔÇ£stop-
timeÔÇØ based | use `-to 00:00:53` | `-ss 00:00:46 -to 00:00:53` |  `-to` is absolute (HH:MM:SS from
the start of the input), while `-t` is relative (seconds after the seek).  ---  ## Correct one-liner
for PowerShell  ```powershell ffmpeg -ss 00:00:46 -to 00:00:53 -i .\static\video\nlx_src.mp4 `
-vf "scale=1280:-2,format=yuv420p" `        -c:v libx264 -crf 23 -preset veryfast -an `
.\static\video\nlx_loop.mp4 ```  * `-ss` **before** `-i` = fast seek (good enough for a background
loop).     If you ever need frame-accurate cuts, place a **second** `-ss` _after_   the `-i`. * `-to
00:00:53` stops exactly at 00:53 ÔçÆ 7-second clip. * `-an` removes audio to keep the loop silent.
Run the command again; the log should now end with something like:  ``` frame=  175 fps=...
time=00:00:07.00 bitrate=... speed=... video:..kB audio:0kB global headers:0kB muxing overhead:...
```  and the new **nlx_loop.mp4** will show a 7-second duration if you do  ```powershell ffmpeg -i
.\static\video\nlx_loop.mp4 -hide_banner ```  ---  ### Quick checklist if FFmpeg still exports the
wrong length  1. **Order of options** preserved?      `-ss` Ô×£ `-to`/`-t` Ô×£ `-i` Ô×£ rest of options Ô×£
**output file**. 2. **Line continuation**:      PowerShell uses back-tick `` ` ``. If you copy the
command as a single    long line you can omit the back-ticks entirely. 3. **Cached video?**
Delete the previous `nlx_loop.mp4` before re-running to be sure youÔÇÖre    opening the fresh file.
Once the 7-second file plays locally you can leave the HTML+CSS embed exactly as we added earlier ÔÇô
the browser will automatically loop the shorter clip.

hero__cta">Request a Free Quote</a>   </div> </section> ```  ---  ## 2. CSS: stacking, readability
and responsive scaling  ```css .video-hero {   position: relative;   width: 100%;   height: 60vh;
/* desktop height */   overflow: hidden;          /* crop anything outside */   display: flex;
/* center content */   align-items: center;   justify-content: center;   padding: 2rem;   box-
sizing: border-box; }  .video-hero__media {   position: absolute;   top: 50%; left: 50%;   width:
auto; height: 100%;   min-width: 100%;   transform: translate(-50%,-50%);   object-fit: cover;
/* fill box, crop edges */   z-index: 1;   filter: brightness(0.6) contrast(1.2) saturate(1.1); }
.video-hero__overlay {   position: absolute;   inset: 0;   background: rgba(0,0,0,0.4);  /* darken

max-width: 800px;   text-align: center;   color: #fff; }  .video-hero__title {   font-size:
clamp(1.75rem, 5vw, 3rem);   margin-bottom: 0.5em;   text-shadow: 0 2px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.7);   line-
height: 1.2; }  .video-hero__subtitle {   font-size: clamp(1rem, 2.5vw, 1.25rem);   margin-bottom:

video fill the frame while you always see the ÔÇ£goodÔÇØ part in the middle.   2. **CSS filters**
(brightness/contrast) tone down busy footage without re-encoding.   3. A **semi-transparent
overlay** (`rgba(0,0,0,.4)`) guarantees white text will read easily.   4. **Text-shadow** adds that
extra legibility lift.   5. **Clamp()** on font sizes keeps your headlines punchy on desktop but
never gigantic on mobile.   6. A **call-to-action** button ties design and functionality together.
With that in place, youÔÇÖll have a hero that:  - **Looks cinematic** (darkened, colour-graded video

00:00:10 ÔåÆ 00:00:15    ffmpeg -ss 00:00:10 -t 5 -i input.mp4 -c copy clip1.mp4     # second clip
from 00:01:00 ÔåÆ 00:01:05    ffmpeg -ss 00:01:00 -t 5 -i input.mp4 -c copy clip2.mp4    ```  2.
**Concatenate them**      Create a plain-text file (`mylist.txt`) listing:    ```    file
'clip1.mp4'    file 'clip2.mp4'    ```    Then run:    ```bash    ffmpeg -f concat -safe 0 -i

output.mp4    ```    - `-an` removes the audio track      - `-movflags +faststart` lets browsers
begin playback before the whole file downloads  4. **Embed with looping**      In your `<video>` tag
just add `loop`:    ```html    <video class="video-hero__media"           src="{{ url_for('static',
filename='video/output.mp4') }}"           autoplay muted loop playsinline>    </video>    ```  ---
## B) One-step ÔÇ£filter_complexÔÇØ (no temp files)  ```bash ffmpeg -i input.mp4 \   -filter_complex "\
[0:v]trim=start=10:end=15,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[v0]; \     [0:v]trim=start=60:end=65,setpts=PTS-
STARTPTS[v1]; \     [v0][v1]concat=n=2:v=1:a=0[outv]" \   -map "[outv]" \   -c:v libx264 -crf 20
-preset veryfast -movflags +faststart \   output.mp4 ``` - `trim` slices out two clips   -
`setpts=PTS-STARTPTS` resets timestamps so they concatenate seamlessly   - `concat=n=2:v=1:a=0`
stitches the two video streams, drops audio (`a=0`)   - rest of flags as above    You now have

All of those ÔÇ£not recognizedÔÇØ errors are PowerShell telling you that it doesnÔÇÖt know what ÔÇ£-vfÔÇØ,
ÔÇ£-c:vÔÇØ, ÔÇ£-anÔÇØ or your output path are, because you hit Enter after the first line and PowerShell
tried to execute each of those lines as its own command. In bash youÔÇÖd split with a backslash ( \ )
but in PowerShell you either need to:  ---  ### 1. Put the entire command on one line  ```powershell
ffmpeg -i "static/video/nlx_loop.mp4" -vf "crop=iw-200:ih:0:0" -c:v libx264 -crf 20 -preset medium
-movflags +faststart -an "static/video/nlx_loop_cropped.mp4" ```  ---  ### 2. Or use PowerShellÔÇÖs
line-continuation backtick (`) at the **end** of each line  ```powershell ffmpeg -i
"static/video/nlx_loop.mp4" `     -vf "crop=iw-200:ih:0:0" `     -c:v libx264 -crf 20 -preset medium
-movflags +faststart `     -an `     "static/video/nlx_loop_cropped.mp4" ```  Note:  - **Backtick**
is PowerShellÔÇÖs continuation character, **not** the backslash. - It must be the very last character
on the lineÔÇöno trailing spaces. - Wrap paths in quotes if they contain spaces (or just always quote
them). - DonÔÇÖt start a new line with `-vf` (or `-c:v`, etc.)ÔÇöthose flags must be part of the ffmpeg
invocation.  ---  Once you run one of those two forms, you should get `nlx_loop_cropped.mp4` in your
`static/video` folder, with the rightmost 200 px chopped off, re-encoded without sound, ready to
loop in your hero.

To preserve as much of your source quality as possible while removing that little ÔÇ£DMG MoriÔÇØ logo
you really want to:  1. **Always crop from your pristine ORIGINAL**, not from an already-encoded
loop file. Every re-encode you do chips away at quality.   2. **Use a very high-quality H.264
encode** (or even lossless) so the only generation loss comes from that single re-encode.   3.
**DonÔÇÖt scale**ÔÇökeep the input resolution intact.  ---  ## Example FFmpeg command  Assuming your
untouched master is at   ``` static/video/nlx_src.mp4 ```   and you just need to chop off the
rightmost 200px (where the watermark lives), you can do:  ```bash ffmpeg \   -i
static/video/nlx_src.mp4 \   -vf "crop=iw-200:ih:0:0" \   -c:v libx264 -crf 18 -preset slow
-movflags +faststart \   -c:a copy \   static/video/nlx_loop.mp4 ```  - `-vf "crop=iw-200:ih:0:0"`
ÔÇô new width = original width minus 200px     ÔÇô full input height     ÔÇô start at `x=0,y=0`   - `-c:v
libx264 -crf 18 -preset slow`     ÔÇô CRF 18 is visually indistinguishable from lossless while still
very sensible for web.     ÔÇô If you really want **no** loss, use `-crf 0 -preset veryslow` (but your
file will balloon).   - `-movflags +faststart`     ÔÇô optimizes MP4 for streaming/web.   - `-c:a
copy`     ÔÇô preserves your original audio track (or use `-an` to drop it).  ---  ## For your 2├ù 5
second snippets concatenation **and** crop in one go  If you still want that spliced 10 second
montage, hereÔÇÖs a single-step `filter_complex` version that: - trims out two 5 s segments   - resets
their timestamps   - crops each   - concatenates them   - keeps only video    ```bash ffmpeg -i
static/video/nlx_src.mp4 \   -filter_complex "\     [0:v]trim=start=10:duration=5,setpts=PTS-
STARTPTS,crop=iw-200:ih:0:0[v0]; \     [0:v]trim=start=30:duration=5,setpts=PTS-
STARTPTS,crop=iw-200:ih:0:0[v1]; \     [v0][v1]concat=n=2:v=1:a=0[outv]\   " \   -map "[outv]" \
-c:v libx264 -crf 18 -preset slow -movflags +faststart \   static/video/nlx_loop.mp4 ```  1.
`trim=start=X:duration=5` picks your 5 s slice.   2. `setpts=PTS-STARTPTS` makes each slice start at
PTS=0 so they glue seamlessly.   3. `crop=iw-200:ih:0:0` removes the 200px watermark region from
each slice.   4. `concat=n=2:v=1:a=0[outv]` stitches the two video streams, dropping audio.   5. Re-
encode once with your high-quality CRF settings.  ---  ### Why this keeps quality high  - **One re-
encode** instead of two or three.   - **CRF 18** is ÔÇ£visually losslessÔÇØ for most people.   - **No
resizing**, so no extra blur/sharpen artifacts.   - **Copying audio** (or dropping once) means
youÔÇÖre not re-encoding sound.  ---  Whenever you tweak cropping or trim points, always run against
your original `.mp4` masterÔÇönever chain crops/encodes off an already-encoded loop. That way you
avoid cumulative quality loss.   Let me know how that works!

colour later.   (Everything uses PowerShell-friendly back-ticks and inline comments.)  ---  ### 1 Ôâú

store the colour in `--page-bg` so you can override it in one place later.  ---  ### 2 Ôâú  Remove the
