Lines ending in **\`** are PowerShell-style continuations ÔÇô copy/paste straight into the file.   *
Anything you must customise is wrapped in `<<< UPPERCASE >>>`.  ---  ## 1  HTML ÔÇô insert the toggle
button & mobile panel  Open **base.html** and, *just after* the existing `<nav>ÔÇª</nav>` block, add:
```html <!-- Hamburger toggle --> <button class="nav-toggle" aria-label="Open navigation" aria-
expanded="false">   <span class="nav-toggle__bar"></span> </button>  <!-- Mobile drawer --> <nav
class="mobile-nav" aria-label="Mobile">   <ul>     <li><a href="{{ url_for('home') }}">Home</a></li>
<li><a href="{{ url_for('about') }}">About</a></li>     <li><a href="{{ url_for('services')
}}">Services</a></li>     <li><a href="{{ url_for('mori_machines') }}">Mori Machines</a></li>
<li><a href="{{ url_for('contact') }}">Contact</a></li>   </ul> </nav> ```  ---  ## 2  CSS ÔÇô styles
& break-point logic   Append this to **static/css/style.css** (below your existing media-query
section):  ```css /* ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ MOBILE HAMBURGER ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ */ .nav-toggle {                        /* clickable
icon  */   position: absolute;                /* hugs left edge  */   top: 0.75rem; left: 1rem;
width: 44px; height: 44px;         /* thumb-size tap  */   display: none;                     /*
hide on desktop */   background: transparent;   border: 0;   z-index: 999;                      /*
above masthead  */ }  .nav-toggle__bar,                    /* three bars      */ .nav-
toggle__bar::before, .nav-toggle__bar::after {   content: '';   display: block;   width: 24px;
height: 3px;   background: #fff;   border-radius: 2px;   transition: transform .3s ease, opacity .3s
ease; } .nav-toggle__bar::before { transform: translateY(-7px); } .nav-toggle__bar::after  {
transform: translateY(4px); }  /*  when menu is open Ô×£ animate into "X"  */ .nav-toggle[aria-
expanded="true"] .nav-toggle__bar {   background: transparent; } .nav-toggle[aria-expanded="true"]
.nav-toggle__bar::before {   transform: translateY(0) rotate(45deg); } .nav-toggle[aria-
expanded="true"] .nav-toggle__bar::after {   transform: translateY(0) rotate(-45deg); }  /* ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ
SLIDE-IN DRAWER ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ */ .mobile-nav {   position: fixed;   top: 0; left: 0;   height: 100vh;   width:
260px;                      /* adjust width */   background: var(--blue);   transform:
translateX(-100%);   transition: transform .3s ease;   padding-top: 4rem;                 /* leave
room for toggle */   z-index: 998; } .mobile-nav.open { transform: translateX(0); }  .mobile-nav ul
{   list-style: none;   margin: 0; padding: 0; } .mobile-nav li { margin: 0; } .mobile-nav a {
display: block;   padding: 1rem 1.5rem;   color: #fff;   font-family: 'Roboto', sans-serif;   font-
weight: 500;   text-decoration: none; } .mobile-nav a:hover {   background: rgba(255,255,255,.08); }
/* ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ RESPONSIVE SWITCH ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ */ @media (max-width: 768px) {   /* show hamburger, hide desktop list
*/   .nav-toggle         { display: block; }   nav ul              { display: none; }   /* desktop
strip */ } ```  ---  ## 3  JavaScript ÔÇô toggle logic  Create **static/js/mobile-nav.js** and paste:
```js document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {   const toggle =
document.querySelector('.nav-toggle');   const drawer = document.querySelector('.mobile-nav');   if
(!toggle || !drawer) return;    toggle.addEventListener('click', () => {     const expanded =
toggle.getAttribute('aria-expanded') === 'true';     toggle.setAttribute('aria-expanded',
!expanded);     drawer.classList.toggle('open');   }); }); ```  Now make sure the file is loaded (at
the bottom of **base.html**, right before `</body>`):  ```html <script src="{{ url_for('static',
filename='js/mobile-nav.js') }}"></script> ```  ---  ## 4  Remove any **old** hamburger leftovers
Search VS Code for:  ``` .nav-toggle .mobile-nav hamburger ```   If you spot earlier experiments
(e.g. `.menu-btn`, `#mobileMenu`, etc.), delete those blocks so they donÔÇÖt clash with the fresh
rules above.  ---  ### Tweaking instructions  (ÔÇ£initiative knobsÔÇØ)  * **Drawer width** ÔÇô change
`width: 260px` (CSS)   * **Break-point** ÔÇô alter `@media (max-width: 768px)` to whichever pixel
width you want the hamburger to appear.   * **Left padding** ÔÇô the button is `left: 1rem`; nudge if
it collides with the logo.   * **Colours / font-family** ÔÇô edit the `.mobile-nav a` block.  Publish
/ hard-refresh ÔÇô youÔÇÖll get a tidy hamburger that slides from the left, overlays the page, and stays
fully editable.

message. Until you save & close it, Git will sit ÔÇ£waitingÔÇØ and your commit wonÔÇÖt finish. HereÔÇÖs what
to do:  1. **Enter your commit message**      - At the very top (above any lines starting with `#`),
type a one-line summary of what you changed.        ```text      Fix mobile nav sliding in from the
right      ``` 2. **Save the file**      - In VS Code: **File ÔåÆ Save** (or Ctrl+S / Ôîÿ+S).   3.
**Close that tab**      - Once itÔÇÖs saved and closed, Git notices and completes the commit.    ---
### What if you just want to abort that commit?  If you opened it by mistake and want to bail out:
```bash git commit --abort ```  That will back out of the in-progress commit and return you to the
shell without recording anything.  ---  ### Shortcut: supply the message on the command line  To
avoid opening the editor at all, you can put your message right in the `git commit` command:
```bash git commit -m "Fix mobile nav sliding in from the right" ```  That way you never drop into
the `COMMIT_EDITMSG` buffer.

the accidental pull:  ```bash git stash push -m "wip: mobile nav tweak" ```  ---  ## 2. Reset your
local branch to exactly match the remote  This drops any stray merge or pull you just did, and
throws away any other local commits you didnÔÇÖt intend:  ```bash git fetch origin git reset --hard
origin/main ```  *(If your main branch is named something else, use that in place of `main`.)*  ---
## 3. Re-apply your nav changes  ```bash git stash pop ```  Now your nav files (the ones you had

That takes you back to exactly where you were right before the pull, no stashing neededÔÇö but if you

Source Control panel  If you prefer the GUI:  1. In the SC panel, type your commit message into the

the ÔÇ£ÔÇªÔÇïÔÇØ menu and choose **Push**.  That will finish your commit and push in one flow.  ---  Give

To collapse that white gap between your `<nav>` strip and your video hero, you donÔÇÖt need to rip out
big chunks of code ÔÇô you just need to zero-out any bottom margin on the nav, and force zero top-
margin on the hero. Add the following at the very bottom of **style.css**, *after* all your existing
rules:  ```css /* ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ NAVÔÇôHERO SPACING RESET ÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇÔöÇ */ nav {   /* win every
cascade and strip out any stray bottom margin */   margin-bottom: 0 !important;   padding-bottom: 0
!important; }  /* force the video-hero to hug the nav with no gap */ nav + .video-hero, main >
.video-hero {   margin-top: 0 !important;   padding-top: 0 !important; } ```  ---  ### Why this
works  - **`margin-bottom: 0 !important` on `nav`** ensures thereÔÇÖs absolutely no space pushed below
your desktop nav bar.   - **`nav + .video-hero`** targets a `.video-hero` section that immediately
follows a `<nav>` (your case on the home page).   - **`main > .video-hero`** covers the edge-case of
a hero block inside `main` (on other pages).   - The `!important` bumps these rules to the very top
of the cascade, so nothing else (including browser defaults or earlier media-query overrides) can
sneak a gap back in.  Paste that at the bottom of **style.css**, save, then refresh your browser.
The hero should now sit flush under the nav, and everything else will stay exactly as you had it.

Below are **five modern, legible Google Fonts** that work well for navigation labels. IÔÇÖve grouped
them by ÔÇ£feelÔÇØ so you can pick the vibe that fits Matford best.  | # | Font | Character | Why it
works for navs | |---|-------|-----------|-----------------------| | 1 | **Poppins (600)** |
Geometric / friendly | Wide letter-forms, very clear at small sizes | | 2 | **Barlow Condensed
(600)** | Industrial / space-saving | Narrow width = long labels fit without wrapping | | 3 | **IBM
Plex Sans (600)** | Professional / technical | Slight humanist touch, great legibility | | 4 | **Exo
(600)** | Futuristic / techy | Subtle squareness echoes CNC/panel aesthetic | | 5 | **Lato (700)** |
Neutral / trustworthy | Clean & familiar, pairs with almost anything |  ---  ## How to try them
(2-minute swap)  1. **Add the import(s)**      Open **`style.css`**, find the very top where the
other `@import` lines live.      Paste one of these lines (comment out the previous one so only one
is active at a time):  ```css /* =====  NAV FONT OPTIONS  ===== */ @import
url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Poppins:wght@600&display=swap');       /* option #1 */
/*@import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Barlow+Condensed:wght@600&display=swap');*/
/* #2 */ /*@import
url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=IBM+Plex+Sans:wght@600&display=swap');*/   /* #3 */
/*@import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Exo:wght@600&display=swap');*/            /*
#4 */ /*@import url("https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Lato:wght@700&display=swap");*/
/* #5 */ ```  > Ô£ö´©Å **Tip:** keep only *one* uncommented at a time while you audition.  2. **Apply
the font to both desktop strip & mobile drawer**      Scroll to the nav section (you already have
`.mobile-nav a` and `nav a`).      Add (or edit) the font-family line exactly **once** under the
shared selectors:  ```css /* -------------  Navigation links ------------- */ nav a, .mobile-nav a {
/* ÔÇªother rulesÔÇª */     font-family: 'Poppins', sans-serif;   /* switch name here when testing */ }
```  That single rule covers:  * The white desktop strip (because of `nav a`) * The blue slide-out
drawer (because of `.mobile-nav a`)  3. **Save ÔåÆ Hard-refresh** (`Ctrl + S`, then browser `Ctrl +
Shift + R`).      Shrink / expand the window to test both layouts.  4. **Try the next font**      ÔÇô
Comment the current `@import` line      ÔÇô Un-comment another one      ÔÇô Change the family name in
`font-family:` to match      ÔÇô Save & refresh.  Repeat until the menu looks ÔÇ£just right,ÔÇØ then
commit your favourite.  ---  ### If you need size tweaks per layout  *Desktop strip only*  ```css
@media (min-width: 769px){   nav a{ font-size: .925rem; }   /* slightly smaller on wide screens */ }
```  *Mobile drawer only*  ```css @media (max-width: 768px){   .mobile-nav a{ font-size: 1.1rem; }
/* bump size for thumb taps */ } ```  ---  Happy type-testing!

### Why the Ô£ë´©Ä ÔÇ£disappearedÔÇØ  After you switched the whole site to **IBM Plex Sans** the plain-text
Ô£ë´©Ä glyph is now rendered by that font.   IBM Plex Sans draws the envelope in **white** (on most

youÔÇÖll add | Pros | Cons | |-----|-----------------|------|------| | **1. Google ÔÇ£Material Symbols
OutlinedÔÇØ icon-font** | 1 ├ù `<link>` in `<head>` and 2 CSS lines | No files to host, scalable,
colour inherits | One extra Google Fonts request | | **2. Tiny inline SVG** | 1 SVG file (313 B) in

|  Pick whichever you prefer ÔÇô both give a blue envelope inside the existing white circle.  ---  ##
Option 1ÔÇéÔÇôÔÇéMaterial Symbols icon-font  ### 1 Ôû¬ Add the font link once (base.html, inside `<head>`)
```html <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Material+Symbols+Outlined:wght@400"
rel="stylesheet"> ```  ### 2 Ôû¬ Replace the old glyph rule in **style.css**  ```css /* simple
placeholder icons ÔÇö now real iconÔÇÉfont */ .icon-mail::before{     font-family: "Material Symbols
Outlined";     content: "mail";                 /* ÔåÉ the iconÔÇÖs name  */     font-size: 18px;
/* tweak if needed    */     line-height: 1;                  /* keeps it centred   */ } ```  ThatÔÇÖs
it ÔÇô the icon inherits `color: var(--blue)` from `.icon-link`, so you get a blue envelope on a white
circle.  ---  ## Option 2ÔÇéÔÇôÔÇéInline SVG (local)  ### 1 Ôû¬ Save this tiny SVG as   `static/images/icon-
mail.svg`  ```svg <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="#0a3d62">
<path d="M2 4h20a2 2 0 0 1 2 2v12a2 2 0 0 1-2 2H2a2            2 0 0 1-2-2V6a2 2 0 0 1 2-2zm10 7

**style.css**  ```css /* simple placeholder icons ÔÇö now SVG */ .icon-mail::before{     content: "";
width: 18px; height: 14px;               /* native 24├ù24 shrunk */     background:
url("/static/images/icon-mail.svg") center/contain no-repeat;     display: block;

made it into `style.css`.     The only `.icon-mail::before` that the browser can see is still the
old one at **line Ôëê 96**:  ```css .icon-mail::before{               /* ÔåÉ still the emoji  */
content: "Ô£ë"; } ```  Emojis ignore CSS `color`, so they stay the OS-white youÔÇÖre seeing.  ---  ##
2-step fix  > **Goal:** blue outlined envelope inside the existing white circle ÔÇô no other layout
changes.  ### Ôæá  Remove the old emoji rule   Delete (or comment-out) the **whole** snippet around
line 96:  ```diff -.icon-mail::before{ -    content:"Ô£ë"; -} ```  ### Ôæí  Drop-in the icon-font rule
**right after `.icon-link`**  ```css /* simple placeholder icons ÔåÆ now real icon-font */ .icon-
mail::before{     font-family: "Material Symbols Outlined";     content: "mail";                  /*
ligature text */     font-size: 18px;                  /* tweak if needed */     line-height: 1;
/* keeps it centred */     /* no colour here ÔåÆ inherits var(--blue) from .icon-link */ } ```  Your
file now looks like  ```css .icon-link{     background:#fff;     color:var(--blue);
/* all icons inherit this */     /* ÔÇªrest unchangedÔÇª */ }  /* Ôû╝ PUT THE NEW BLOCK HERE Ôû╝ */ .icon-
mail::before{     font-family:"Material Symbols Outlined";     content:"mail";     font-size:18px;
line-height:1; } /* Ôû▓ end new block */ ```  ---  ### One-time check in **base.html**  You already
pasted the Google-fonts link; just make sure it is **inside `<head>` and only once** :  ```html
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Material+Symbols+Outlined" rel="stylesheet">
```  *(You donÔÇÖt need the weight / fill parameters unless you want filled icons later.)*  ---  ##
Test  1. **Save** `style.css` (`Ctrl + S`)   2. Hard-refresh the page (`Ctrl + Shift + R` or Ôçº F5)
3. The mail glyph should now be the same brand-blue as the phone and stay perfectly centred in the

Select the `<span class="icon-mail">`   * Check the **Styles** cascade ÔÇô you should see the new
`.icon-mail::before` rule.     If itÔÇÖs crossed out or missing, something is still overriding it;
